articles.headline: Bush v. Gore Set to Outlast Its Beneficiary
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court’s decision was never intended to set a precedent, but it is turning out to have lasting value.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision was never intended to set a precedent, but it is turning out to have lasting value.

articles.headline: Living With the Airline Bag Fee
articles.snippet: Despite the cries of protests when airlines started charging for checked luggage, it seems baggage fees are a change we can live with after all.
articles.abstract: Despite the cries of protests when airlines started charging for checked luggage, it seems baggage fees are a change we can live with after all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans seem to be enamored of change these days. And despite the cries of protests when airlines started charging for checked luggage, it seems baggage fees are a change we can live with after all.

articles.headline: Car Slump Jolts Toyota, Halting 70 Years of Gain
articles.snippet: The grim forecast from Toyota is the latest sign of the global auto industry’s slowdown after years of profits and expansion.
articles.abstract: The grim forecast from Toyota is the latest sign of the global auto industry’s slowdown after years of profits and expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: A surprisingly grim forecast from Toyota Motor on Monday  that it will lose money this fiscal year on its vehicle business for the first time in seven decades  is the latest sign of the global auto industry’s sharp slowdown after years of rising profits and rapid expansion.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Foreign Automakers in the U.S. Cut Back
articles.snippet: Although they have ample credit, foreign-owned carmakers with U.S. operations are facing slowing sales.
articles.abstract: Although they have ample credit, foreign-owned carmakers with U.S. operations are facing slowing sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Sales are off and production is down, so workers at the Toyota Tundra truck factory here are taking classes: how to handle tools safely, how to get along better with colleagues of varying backgrounds. Some have even cleaned local parks and fed the hungry while collecting Toyota paychecks.

articles.headline: For HSBC, Questions of Vitality
articles.snippet: As the bank faces a sharp slowdown in the emerging markets where it earns the bulk of its profit, many investors are questioning HSBC’s ability to maintain its exalted standing.
articles.abstract: As the bank faces a sharp slowdown in the emerging markets where it earns the bulk of its profit, many investors are questioning HSBC’s ability to maintain its exalted standing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Through more than a year of giant bailouts and bankruptcies, HSBC was one of the few big banks to emerge with its reputation largely intact.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: As Economy Dips, Arrests for Shoplifting Soar
articles.snippet: Police departments across the country say arrests are 10 percent to 20 percent higher this year than last.
articles.abstract: Police departments across the country say arrests are 10 percent to 20 percent higher this year than last.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard R. Johnson is the first to admit it was a bad idea.
articles.byline: By IAN URBINA  and SEAN D. HAMILL

articles.headline: For Craft Sales, the Recession Is a Help
articles.snippet: A boom in sales of crafts and related supplies contrasts with poor results for traditional retailers, like electronics retailers and department stores.
articles.abstract: A boom in sales of crafts and related supplies contrasts with poor results for traditional retailers, like electronics retailers and department stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Feeling the pinch of the economic downturn, some holiday gift-givers are saving money this year by making their own presents or — for those who lack the time or talent — buying handmade gifts from others.

articles.headline: Irregularity Uncovered at IndyMac
articles.snippet: Two months before IndyMac Bancorp collapsed, a federal banking regulator allowed it to backdate a capital infusion, a Treasury Department investigator said.
articles.abstract: Two months before IndyMac Bancorp collapsed, a federal banking regulator allowed it to backdate a capital infusion, a Treasury Department investigator said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two months before IndyMac Bancorp collapsed in July, at a cost of $8.9 billion to taxpayers, a top federal banking regulator allowed the bank to backdate a capital infusion and gloss over its deepening problems, the Treasury Department’s independent investigator said Monday.
